Award.AwardTitle: Participant Support for a GSA Thompson Field Forum: Processes controlling the growth and evolution of continental batholiths, Coast Mountains British Columbia Canada
Award.AbstractNarration: This proposal provides support for student participation and early career faculty to participate in a Geological Society of Geological Society of America Thompson Field Forum entitled." Participants of the forum will examine important field relationships along a transect across the Coast Mountains batholith between Terrace and Prince Rupert Canada that will be held August 12 to 17, 2018. Along with the field trip, evening technical sessions will involve talks and discussion regarding processes of magmatism, continental growth, and collisional, accretionary, and translational tectonics. The Coast Mountains Batholith, British Columbia is an ideal location for forum because is one of the largest magmatic complexes on earth and it exhibits significant along strike and cross strike variations in structure, compostion, and depths from which the rocks have been exhumed. In particular, the forum will examine the concept of high flux magmatic events. A growing body of data from upper and lower crustal exposure of batholiths around the globe indicate that most batholiths are comprised of intrusions that are emplaced during relatively brief time periods (tens of millions of years) known as High Flux Events (HFE). Field stops and discussions will focus on locations that are important for discerning mechanisms that trigger these high flux magmatic events. Specific topics to be addressed during the forum include 1) What are the sources for batholith magmas; 2) What are the triggering mechanisms for high flux magmatic events; and 3) What is the magnitude and significance of large-scale translational faulting on batholith architecture? Support for this forum will provide assistance for ten students and early career faculty to attend and benefit from this unique activity. The travel and logistical support for the forum will directly enhance science education in an important STEM discipline through the participants increased awareness and ability to integrate field, analytical, and model based science. Participants will be in an excellent position to disseminate these ideas to the research community and the general public, and the experience will greatly enhance their future scientific careers. A publicly available document describing field stops and related geological syntheses will be produced by the Geological Society of America.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Summary

The National Science Foundation provided critical financial support for geoscience graduate students and young investigators to attend the Geological Society of America Thompson field forum "Processes Controlling the Growth and Evolution of Continental Batholiths, Coast Mountains, British Columbia Canada Terrace, British Columbia, Canada". This forum convened 27 geoscientists in Terrace to discuss the processes responsible for production of large intrusions of molten rock or magma (batholiths) into continents. These influxes of magma are important because they are a primary process in the growth of continents and produce mountains. The forum focused on how existing data for the Coast Mountains batholith can inform modern paradigms for batholith growth and magma genesis. The forum included a five-day field excursion along the Skeena River corridor between Terrace and Prince Rupert that provides a unique opportunity to see rocks which can be used to test modern orogenic models using new techniques and expanded datasets. 

Intellectual Merit

Participants in the field forum were challenged to use the use their knowledge, published data, and the well-exposed rocks in order to address the following questions: 

1 What are the processes and conditions responsible for the temporal and spatial variations in magmatism in the Coast Mountains?

2 What processes are responsible for the changes in thickening and later thinning of the crust during emplacement of the magmas that formed the batholith?

3 What are the causal relationships between magma generation, deformation, and heating of the crust?

4 What is the contribution of sediments, which formed at the surface, to magmatism? 

5 What drives melting and magma production within the crust?

Broader Impacts

The National Science Foundation support successfully facilitated geoscience students and young scientists to attend the Geological Society of America Field Forum. This funding was used to support 10 attendees to participate in the field forum. Six of the students supported were women and four were men.

The forum motivated young geoscientists to study batholiths, and the growth and evolution of continental crust. Although it is too early to be sure how many new ideas will develop into research projects, there are many ideas under discussion. The leaders of the forum are very enthusiastic about future developments. 

Finally, some of the participants stayed an additional day and were treated to a full day look at porphyry copper mineralization freshly exposed by retreating ice along the eastern flank of the Coast Mountains. This unusual opportunity afforded students exposure to copper mineralization, and the techniques for mining exploration and development.
